16.27.text:
Well, I'm slightly out of kilter being
in a creative environment, traditionally,

23.08.text: because if you ask people who know me,

25.78.text:
"Is Claire creative?" traditionally,
I can't draw, I'm not an actress,

33.16.text:
and years ago I would have said
I wasn't creative.

36.06.text:
But the whole world
has completely changed.

38.63.text:
We're in the modern 21st-century
and every single person,

44.80.text:
any walk of life can be creative
and can be enterprising.

49.12.text: I've learnt over the last ten years

51.33.text:
since I left university
that I'm very good at ideas,

55.54.text:
I'm very good at problem solving,
I'm very good at spotting opportunities,

60.01.text:
I'm very, very enterprising
and entrepreneurial.

63.12.text:
And in hand, creativity goes
hand-in-hand with that,

69.58.text:
I talk to people a lot about what's
happened since The Apprentice,

73.85.text:
starting a business,
climbing the ladder, selling a business.

77.54.text:
They say, "How did it all start?
Did you have a big master plan?"

81.10.text:
When I was sat in your seats 15 years ago, 
I'm hopefully not too over-the-hill at 32,

86.87.text:
I had absolutely no clue 
what I wanted to do

89.82.text:
and I've made some mistakes along the way. 
I've learnt. I've been creative.

94.49.text:
And I've really
thought on my own two feet.

97.34.text:
I call the 'Light Bulb Moment' --
is absolutely critical to what's really helped me

103.68.text: over the last ten years in being successful.

106.08.text:
And people talk about when things
just fall into place and "I just knew…."

110.23.text: I've met so many successful people

112.30.text:
over the last couple of years 
from all different walks of life,

115.81.text:
from people in Formula 1, 
to music, to cookery,

118.87.text:
to big entrepreneurs
like Richard Branson and Lord Sugar.

124.48.text:
And that moment can happen
sometimes when you're 16.

127.97.text:
I know people, entrepreneurs,
people who found that walk of life.

131.62.text:
People who were 21, like myself,
I discovered what I wanted to do.

136.12.text:
People who are 60, like my mum
who's just had a big career change.

141.10.text:
And it all comes down
to the 'Light Bulb Moment'.

145.59.text:
I was thinking about it 
as I was driving here today,

148.10.text:
it's quite wishy-washy, sometimes
a creative term and I thought,

151.49.text:
"What does it really mean to me?" 
Now, I like to keep things simple

155.49.text:
because I think if you keep it simple,
you take it away,

157.97.text:
and you keep it in your head
and you'll take it through life.

169.62.text:
'Cause when all those three things
come together,

172.28.text:
so you know your subject matter,
you've got some experience,

175.49.text:
and you've got that instinct,
and all three drop together,

178.76.text:
that's when you have the moment
"I know what I can do."

183.02.text:
So, over the last ten years,
I have relied on Light Bulb Moments.

188.06.text:
I haven't had a big master plan,
I never left school.

190.84.text:
When I was at 16, 17, 18 
and I went to University saying

194.80.text:
"I'm going to be an entrepreneur,
I'm going to go on a show

197.58.text:
with one of the biggest entrepreneurs 
in the country and have my own business."

203.56.text:
I left school and I went to University
and I did medicine.

208.58.text:
My 'Light Bulb Moment'
from studying medicine at University

213.21.text:
is "You've got to be passionate
and love what you do".

217.44.text:
It was too restrictive, 
it was too blinkered,

220.46.text:
it wasn't for me, but I've learnt 
my 'Light Bulb Moment',

223.08.text:
after being there for six months, 
this just is not for me.

229.50.text: So, again, nothing to do with creativity.

232.61.text:
I went on and I studied
Equine Science at University.

238.45.text:
-- I had a wake-up call 
when I was at University

240.98.text:
that this was not going to take me in life 
where I wanted to be.

244.20.text:
I needed a challenge,
I wanted a certain lifestyle,

247.74.text:
I wanted to really push myself
and push my boundaries,

251.16.text:
and I was always looking for that curiosity
and to see how far I could take myself.

255.70.text:
I've thrown myself out of planes,
next year I'm climbing Everest for charity,

260.27.text:
I'm always looking
to see what you can do.

263.17.text:
Ask yourself when was the last time 
you really challenged yourself,

266.91.text:
when was the last time 
you tried something new,

269.34.text: you really push yourself to the limit,

271.03.text:
'cause it's amazing when you do that
what you really can achieve.

275.65.text:
I'm very, very open-minded
and I think all of us here

280.15.text: should look at ourselves like sponges.

283.00.text:
Somebody said this to me
in the early days of my career.

286.04.text:
He said, "Be a sponge, absorb,
take in as much information as you can."

291.26.text:
The days are long gone when people
used to put people into boxes.

295.10.text:
If you were good at art,
you were creative.

297.57.text:
If you were good at history,
you were an academic.

300.89.text:
If you were good at business,
you were an entrepreneur.

303.20.text: Those blinkers are completely off now.

311.28.text:
and that's woven
into any single career you do.

314.30.text:
So I lifted my brain, opened my mind up,
and I accelerated up the career ladder,

320.85.text:
learning about
something I knew nothing about.

324.34.text:
With the right attitude,
you can learn anything.

327.86.text:
A month ago,
I was taught how to lay brick walls

331.10.text:
and change engine oil
at an event I went to.

333.97.text:
Never done that before.
I've never climbed Everest before.

337.62.text:
With the right attitude,
being open-minded, being enterprising,

342.42.text:
being creative, the world
is absolutely your blank canvas.

346.03.text:
You can go out there
and achieve great things.

349.21.text:
So, before The Apprentice, I climbed
a ladder and I learnt about business.

353.74.text:
I learnt about this creative, entrepreneurial 
environment I knew nothing about.

358.34.text:
I worked for the brand leader in beauty,
I learnt about marketing,

362.14.text:
I learnt about social media, I learnt
about how to persuade consumers

365.86.text:
to walk into your store
and buy your product.

370.32.text:
Again, I don't draw, I can't play
a musical instrument, I'm not an actress.

375.10.text:
But in my own way,
I found my channel to be creative.

378.40.text:
I then moved on
to learn about spreadsheets.

381.81.text:
Now how could you ever think that
a spreadsheet could be creative?

387.16.text:
and finding opportunities 
and working ways to find solutions,

391.12.text: what I did for this company,

392.74.text:
that's being creative,
that's finding a solution to a problem,

397.60.text:
Taking an idea
and watching it grow and develop.

403.67.text:
Being creative with consumers,
coming up with ideas.

407.09.text:
How do you get us to spend more money?
How do you excite us in-store?

413.79.text:
-- you're constantly having to come up
with ideas, and problems, and solutions.

417.99.text:
And this is the job
I was doing before The Apprentice.

420.75.text:
So, for somebody, 
who when I was growing up

422.64.text: I thought I was really, really uncreative,

425.75.text:
because I was pouring
all these typical traditional courses,

430.06.text: I was doing very well learning

432.39.text:
about very exciting, business creative
entrepreneurial environments.

438.11.text:
Going in The Apprentice, 
12 weeks of Business Boot Camp,

442.62.text:
I personally don't think you get 
a more enterprising, creative experience ever.

448.33.text:
You jump from selling fish on a market,
coming up with ideas

451.95.text:
how you're going to sell, 
how you're going to win,

454.56.text:
to pitching to a global president of one 
of the largest advertising companies in the world.

459.68.text:
It literally was 12 weeks of 20 hour days
of creative thinking,

466.22.text:
thinking of ideas,
coming up with solutions.

469.50.text: It's very, very challenging and I loved it.

474.62.text:
And exactly what it says on the slide,
'Rising To The Challenge'.

478.54.text:
The people who say to me,
"I'd love to go on The Junior Apprentice",

482.32.text:
"I'd love to go on The Apprentice",
all of us can.

485.55.text: It takes five minutes to do it.

488.15.text:
To take the risk, take the blinkers off,
have a go and push yourself

493.60.text: and see what you can do.

495.87.text: So, I left The Apprentice two years ago.

502.03.text:
In front of 11 million people I lost
but sometimes life doesn't go the way you want it to

506.86.text: and I chose to start a business.

510.96.text:
I took two months after The Apprentice
to decide, to gether my information,

516.47.text: to prepare, to really think about it,

519.76.text:
because my PIE,
my instinct in the PIE was unsure.

524.30.text: I had over 500 job offers and I wasn't --

531.07.text:
Now, starting a business
is very, very creative.

534.65.text:
As an entrepreneur,
you have an idea and you take a risk,

540.26.text:
and you take the risk to make
that idea turn into reality.

544.80.text:
It's very scary. I compare the experience
to jumping out of a plane.

548.48.text:
When you're all set 15,000 feet 
at the edge of a plane and somebody says,

552.60.text:
"Do you want to jump?"
In reality, you don't want to jump.

556.13.text:
But you go for it and you push yourself,
you challenge your boundaries

560.14.text:
and starting a business from scratch,
you're not being given a task,

564.48.text:
it's your idea, 
it's your business plan,

567.59.text:
it's your baby, that was 
the 'Light Bulb Moment' for me.

571.31.text:
I slept on it for two months
and I woke up and I thought,

574.23.text: "The idea of not doing this is not possible.

577.85.text: I've got to see if it happens."

579.87.text: Now, that is the true sense of an entrepreneur.

582.18.text: They will go through with their actions.

586.91.text:
I started a business after The Apprentice 
which I sold at the beginning of this year

591.70.text:
and now I work with young people 
all over the country.

594.49.text:
And that's why it's an absolute privilege
to be here today,

597.23.text:
because you are a beacon
for thousands of schools

600.14.text:
who will be logging onto
the website watching this event.

603.04.text:
You are setting the standard
for so many other schools to follow,

606.38.text:
so it's a real privilege for me to be here
and talking to you in an audience.

610.62.text:
I'm very, very passionate about
working with young people

615.34.text: you could be the next Richard Bransons,

618.94.text:
the next Karren Bradys,
you are the next stars of the future

622.80.text: and all of you are enterprising,

624.87.text:
all of you are creative
in whatever walk of life you want to do.

628.76.text:
I was with Alan Sugar
a couple of months ago.

631.29.text:
He's a huge supporter
of Backing Young Britain.

634.92.text:
talking to the Prime Minister about 
how people need to approach things differently.

641.77.text: We need to take the blinkers off,

643.66.text: we need to stop putting people into boxes,

646.26.text: and being a lot more open-minded.

648.41.text: So, today, I'm putting myself in that position.

651.73.text:
When I said to people that
I was presenting a creative academy,

654.74.text:
they said, "You're not creative."
Well, I am.

657.56.text:
I'm an entrepreneur.
We're all creative in different ways.

660.90.text:
So, here I am,
I'm pushing myself out of my boundaries.

665.24.text:
All of these people
work with young people.

669.09.text:
Two of them are my businesses, 
most of them are Government organisations

672.82.text: and when I was young we didn't have --

674.87.text:
-- 'when I was young' 
I sound really old now saying that,

677.59.text:
but when I was your age,
we didn't have any of this.

681.00.text:
So, as young people,
please, be sponges.

684.30.text:
Open yourselves up,
take the blinkers off,

687.16.text:
and grab all the opportunities
you can, like you are today.

690.61.text:
The fact you're sat in this audience,
and you've made the effort to come.

696.22.text:
So, that's all from me.
I'm conscious of the time.

703.08.text:
I have embraced some form
of creativity in technology.

707.28.text:
So, interested, hands in the air, in students.
Who's on Twitter?

713.33.text:
Twitter is going to be the number one
marketing tool over the next year

717.67.text:
and there's lots and lots of interesting,
some really creative people on there.

721.87.text:
So, thank you very much,
I hope you enjoy the morning,

724.98.text: and thank you very much for your time.
